name: resistor production, auxilliaries and energy use | resistor, auxilliaries and energy use | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3021/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of resistors over all types of resistors. There is no distinction between the different types of resisitors produced. Data for auxiliaries, energy, emissions and waste are taken from the Swedish LCI database, from two datasets of Swiss resistor producing companies  and based on estimations from the resistor production. As the raw material input is taken into account in the respective resistor datasets this dataset has no input of raw materials. The production efforts represent not a specific resistor type and have thus, accordingly higher uncertainties.

From reception of electronic components, raw materials and auxiliares at the factory gate.

This dataset includes auxillary and energy consumption, emissions (air, water) and waste amounts, as well as an estimation of the efforts for transportation and of the infrastructure for the production of resistors.
category: C:Manufacturing/26:Manufacture of computer, electronic and optical products/261:Manufacture of electronic components and boards/2610:Manufacture of electronic components and boards

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data from literature and one global producer â€“ here representing the global situation.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average technology for the production of resistors and potentiometers - comprising terminmation printing; resistive body printing; glass coat printing; laser trimming; substrate stripping (SMT) resp. ceramic rods; deposition processes; ageing; capping (THT) resp. printing; curing; punching; revetting; molding (ptoentiom.)

exchanges.description:
A resistor is a two-terminal electrical or electronic component that resists an electric current by producing a voltage drop between its terminals in accordance with Ohm's law - the electrical resistance is equal to the voltage drop across the resistor divided by the current through the resistor. In general, a resistor is used to create a known voltage-to-current ratio in an electric circuit. (Wikipedia (2007)). There are, for example Precision Wirewound, NIST Standards, Power Wirewound, Fuse Resistors, Carbon Composition, Carbon Film, Metal Film, Foil, Filament Wound, and Power Film Resistors - and each single of these resistors has a useful purpose. Knowing the current in a circuit, a resistor can be used to create a known potential difference that is proportional to this current. This means then also that if the potential difference between two points in a circuit is known, a resistor can be used to create a known current proportional to that difference. Resistors can also be used to limit the current that passes through other components - e.g. through light-emitting diodes (LED). Further usages of resistors cover e.g. the regulation of CD motors, the voltage reduction of signals (-> attenuator) or the minimization of signal reflections (-> line terminator).
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
